properties.Title: Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: This Alert is issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. If you are returning to Canada from foreign travel, you MUST self-isolate for 14 days. This includes travel from the US, which now has more COVID 19 cases than any country in the world. It’s the law. For more information on COVID 19 visit: Saskatchewan.ca COVID 19

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong easterly winds with gusts near 100 km/h continue. These gusty winds are also producing some blowing snow. Extreme winds are expected weaken overnight and become light on Saturday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Colorado low will affect the province of Quebec Sunday and Monday. Rainfall amounts of 25 to 50 millimetres are expected for the southern part of the province. Areas from Abitibi toward Mont-Tremblant as well as the northern part of the Eastern Townships could also see some snow. A very brief period of freezing rain is also possible during the transition from rain-snow. Flooding is possible in low lying areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T19:25:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-28T03:26:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3502795338.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Colorado low will affect the province of Quebec Sunday and Monday. Snowfall amounts of more than 15 centimetres are possible for Central Quebec. However, precipitation amounts could greatly vary according to region as temperatures will be near the freezing mark. Some areas near and south of the St. Lawrence could see primarily rain, while snowfall amounts of 25 centimetres are likely locally over higher terrain. A very brief period of freezing rain is also possible during the transition from rain to snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult in some areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T19:26:18-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, and Rigolet and vicinity. Time span: tonight until Saturday evening. Remarks: Northeasterly to northwesterly winds gusting to 60 or 70 km/h will combine with the fresh snowfall to reduce visibility in blowing snow at times tonight and Saturday, especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-28T17:22:25-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard Saturday afternoon and night. On Saturday, another low pressure system will track through the area bringing strong winds and more accumulating snow. Conditions will deteriorate to sustained blizzard Saturday afternoon as northwesterlies gusting to 70 or 80 km/h develop along with up to 5 cm of fresh snow. Near zero visibilities at times are likely. The blizzard will continue through the night before easing Sunday morning as the skies clear and winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T19:58:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-28T03:59:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3941268945.2020
Area: Arviat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Rain will change to snow this evening and become heavy when an Arctic front arrives. Along with the heavy snow, the Arctic front will bring northeast winds gusting to 60 km/h giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. About 15 cm of snow is expected tonight with an additional 5 to 15 on Saturday. Total snowfall accumulations are expected to reach near 30 cm by Saturday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T15:12:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T23:13:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1151080312.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass

properties.Summary:

Remarks: The snow will change through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain this evening from Norman Bay to Lodge Bay and to freezing drizzle of flurries overnight from Cartwright to Black Tickle. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near minus 55 are expected to develop overnight then moderate on Saturday as temperatures rise. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

Area: Cambridge Bay, Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Adverse Winter Driving Conditions Due to Heavy Snow This Weekend. An unseasonably cool spring storm will deliver significant snow to the high mountain passes of southern B.C. beginning this evening. Snow will continue through the day on Saturday as the system pushes across British Columbia. In the wake of the system on Sunday, intense bursts of flurries will add further accumulations. Gusty winds will reduce visibilities in blowing snow, particularly on Sunday. The Coquihalla Highway, Hope to Merritt segment, could receive 30 to 40 cm by Sunday evening, making for challenging travel conditions. Allison Pass, the Okanagan Connector, Rogers Pass and Kootenay Pass could see 15 to 25 cm by Sunday night. Snow levels will be unseasonably low, hovering between 1100 and 1400 metres. A transition from rain at the lower elevations to heavy snow near the passes will make for adverse winter driving conditions. Motorists are encouraged to consider delaying travel plans until early next week when the snow will ease in the mountains. Drivers should be prepared for winter driving conditions and are reminded that winter tires are mandatory until April 30th. Please check the highway forecasts before heading out and stay tuned for potential snowfall warnings. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T12:09:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T20:10:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2228822658.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada
